title: Chief Complaint
content: Right hand minimally displaced dorsal cortex triquetral fracture with associated right thumb radial-sided numbness and tingling following a fall on an outstretched right hand on September 11th, 2025.
instruction: What is the main complaint of the patient, give a one liner detailed note. Only include hand related surgery and issues.

title: History of present illness
content: A 72-year-old right-hand dominant female presents with a right dorsal cortex triquetral fracture sustained on September 11th, 2025 after falling on an uneven sidewalk and landing on an outstretched right hand. Since the injury, she has been wearing a removable wrist brace, and pain has been manageable with homeopathic and over-the-counter pain medications. She endorses persistent right thumb radial-sided numbness and tingling since the injury and initiation of the brace. The symptoms have not improved with current management. She reports no significant changes in symptoms over time, but notes that the numbness and tingling are localized to the radial side of the right thumb and extend proximally along the radial digital nerve. The symptoms are not alleviated by rest or activity modification. She has not undergone any surgical intervention or formal physical therapy. The condition has impacted her ability to perform fine motor tasks related to her occupation as an artist. She denies any recent trauma or changes in medication use. The patient is concerned about the persistent symptoms and their effect on her daily activities and artistic work.
instruction:

Document any prior treatments or remedies the patient has attempted, noting their efficacy. Describe how these symptoms impact the patient's daily activities, overall well-being, and quality of life. title: Imaging
content: X-rays today show a dorsal cortex fracture of the triquetrum. Additionally, osteophytes are noted in the interphalangeal joint of the right thumb. A follow-up ultrasound of the right index finger is recommended to assess a 0.5 cm by 0.5 cm soft tissue mass on the radial side of the proximal interphalangeal joint, which is soft, mobile, and non-tender to palpation.

title: Plan
content: Continue use of removable wrist brace for approximately four to six weeks. Place patient in a new, better-fitting wrist brace today to allow for improved thumb mobilization and to alleviate symptoms of radial-sided numbness and tingling in the right thumb. Encourage continued use of fingers of the affected side as tolerated. Repeat X-rays in two to three weeks to assess for occult fractures and monitor healing progression. Schedule follow-up ultrasound of the right index finger to evaluate the soft tissue mass. Return to clinic in two to three weeks.
